title: Ezekiel Chapter 12 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 12 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 12 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 12.

questions.question: Who is addressed as 'Son of man' in Ezekiel 12?
options: Ezekiel
David
Moses
Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Ezekiel
questions.explanation: The chapter addresses 'Son of man', referring to Ezekiel, as seen in multiple verses such as Ezekiel 12:2.

questions.question: What is the condition of the house that Ezekiel dwells in according to Ezekiel 12:2?
options: Rebellious
Faithful
Blessed
Obedient
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellious
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:2 calls the house rebellious, stating they have eyes to see but do not see, and ears to hear but do not hear.

questions.question: What action was Ezekiel commanded to do as a sign to the house of Israel?
options: Prepare stuff for removing and carry it out in their sight
Build an altar
Write a scroll
Offer a sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare stuff for removing and carry it out in their sight
questions.explanation: Ezekiel was commanded to prepare stuff for removing and carry it out in their sight as a sign, as described in Ezekiel 12:3.

questions.question: When was Ezekiel to bring forth his stuff for removing?
options: By day
At night
At noon
At dawn
questions.correctAnswer: By day
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:4 instructs him to bring forth his stuff by day in their sight.

questions.question: What was Ezekiel instructed to do with the wall in their sight?
options: Dig through it
Paint it
Build upon it
Break it with stones
questions.correctAnswer: Dig through it
questions.explanation: Ezekiel was told to dig through the wall in their sight, as stated in Ezekiel 12:5.

questions.question: Why was Ezekiel to cover his face while carrying his stuff?
options: So he would not see the ground
To hide from enemies
To show humility
To protect from dust
questions.correctAnswer: So he would not see the ground
questions.explanation: Ezekiel was to cover his face so he would not see the ground, as a sign set by God, according to Ezekiel 12:6.

questions.question: What is the significance of Ezekiel's actions of carrying stuff and digging through the wall?
options: They are a sign to the house of Israel
They are a ritual of purification
They are a call to war
They represent building a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: They are a sign to the house of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel's actions were a sign to the house of Israel as explained in Ezekiel 12:6 and 12:11.

questions.question: What was the burden mentioned in Ezekiel 12:10 concerning?
options: The prince in Jerusalem and all the house of Israel
The temple sacrifices
The harvest of the fields
The construction of a wall
questions.correctAnswer: The prince in Jerusalem and all the house of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:10 states the burden concerned the prince in Jerusalem and all the house of Israel among them.

questions.question: What will happen to the prince among the people according to Ezekiel 12?
options: He will go into captivity to Babylon
He will reign victorious
He will build a new city
He will be healed miraculously
questions.correctAnswer: He will go into captivity to Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:13 states that the prince will be taken to Babylon to the land of the Chaldeans.

questions.question: What will happen to those who help the prince, according to Ezekiel 12:14?
options: They will be scattered and pursued by the sword
They will be honored
They will be given land
They will be forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: They will be scattered and pursued by the sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:14 says those who help the prince will be scattered toward every wind and pursued by the sword.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel was told to eat his bread with trembling and drink his water with carefulness.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:18 instructs him to eat bread with quaking and drink water with trembling and carefulness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 12:20, the cities that are inhabited shall be filled with abundance.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:20 states that the cities that are inhabited shall be laid waste and the land shall be desolate.

questions.question: True or False: The proverb in Israel about 'The days are prolonged, and every vision faileth' will no longer be used according to Ezekiel 12.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:23 declares this proverb will cease and will no longer be used.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezekiel 12:25: 'For I am the LORD: I will speak, and the word that I shall speak shall come to pass; it shall be no more ______.'
options: prolonged
forgotten
hidden
ignored
questions.correctAnswer: prolonged
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:25 ends with 'it shall be no more prolonged' referring to God's word coming to pass without delay.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 12:27, what do the people of Israel say about the visions?
options: They are for many days to come and far off
They are immediate and urgent
They are irrelevant
They are already fulfilled
questions.correctAnswer: They are for many days to come and far off
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:27 states the people say the visions are for many days to come and times far off.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 12 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 12 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 12 teach us about obedience and trust in God's Word when facing difficult circumstances?
options: By following God's instructions exactly, even if others do not understand
By acting only when others agree with us
By waiting for favorable conditions before obeying God
By ignoring God's commands if they seem hard
questions.correctAnswer: By following God's instructions exactly, even if others do not understand
questions.explanation: Ezekiel obeyed God's command to prepare and remove his belongings publicly, even though the house of Israel was rebellious and did not understand (Ezekiel 12:3-7). This shows the importance of trusting and obeying God regardless of others' reactions (Ezekiel 12:2, 12:25).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement because others do not listen to their witness. Based on Ezekiel 12, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Continue faithfully as a sign to others, even if they reject the message
Stop sharing because people are rebellious
Change your message to please others
Only share when people show interest
questions.correctAnswer: Continue faithfully as a sign to others, even if they reject the message
questions.explanation: God set Ezekiel as a sign to the rebellious house of Israel, and he obeyed even though they did not listen (Ezekiel 12:6, 12:10-11). This teaches perseverance in faithful witness despite rejection (Ezekiel 12:2, 12:9).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 12 illustrate humility and submission before God in trials?
options: By covering his face to avoid seeing the ground when going into captivity
By boasting about his faithfulness publicly
By refusing to obey God’s commands
By blaming others for his troubles
questions.correctAnswer: By covering his face to avoid seeing the ground when going into captivity
questions.explanation: Ezekiel covered his face so he would not see the ground as a sign of submission and humility in captivity (Ezekiel 12:6, 12:12). This shows trusting God’s plan even when it involves hardship (Ezekiel 12:13-15).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 12 teach about the importance of faithfulness in small acts of obedience?
options: Faithfulness in small acts like preparing and carrying belongings publicly reflects trust in God
Only large acts of faithfulness matter to God
Obedience is optional when others don’t notice
Small acts have no spiritual significance
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness in small acts like preparing and carrying belongings publicly reflects trust in God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel’s careful obedience in small, visible acts (preparing, digging, carrying) was a sign to Israel and demonstrated faithfulness (Ezekiel 12:3-7, 12:11). God honors obedience in all things (Ezekiel 12:25).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 12, how should believers respond when God's promises seem delayed or unclear?
options: Trust that God’s word will come to pass without delay
Assume God has forgotten and give up
Ignore God’s promises and rely on human plans
Wait indefinitely without action
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God’s word will come to pass without delay
questions.explanation: God declares that no more vain visions or delayed words will occur; His word will be fulfilled promptly (Ezekiel 12:23-25, 12:28). Believers should trust God's timing and promises.

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity in daily life can be learned from Ezekiel's actions in chapter 12?
options: Obey God's commands openly and honestly despite opposition
Hide your actions to avoid criticism
Compromise your values when pressured
Act only when it is easy
questions.correctAnswer: Obey God's commands openly and honestly despite opposition
questions.explanation: Ezekiel openly obeyed God's command to remove his belongings publicly, demonstrating integrity and obedience even when others were rebellious (Ezekiel 12:3-7, 12:9-11).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 12 encourage believers to maintain hope and perseverance through trials?
options: God will preserve a remnant who will declare His name among nations
All will be destroyed without exception
Give up hope during hardship
Only focus on personal comfort
questions.correctAnswer: God will preserve a remnant who will declare His name among nations
questions.explanation: God promises to leave a few who survive sword, famine, and pestilence to declare their abominations and His name among the nations (Ezekiel 12:16), encouraging perseverance and hope.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 12 teaches that God's word is reliable and will be fulfilled in the days of the rebellious house.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: God promises that in the days of the rebellious house, His word will be spoken and performed without delay (Ezekiel 12:25).

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 12 indicates that visions and prophesies will continue to be delayed and uncertain among Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: God says that no more vain visions or flattering divinations will occur; the days are at hand and the effect of every vision will be fulfilled (Ezekiel 12:23-24).

questions.question: A believer wonders how to witness faithfully when those around are rebellious and indifferent. According to Ezekiel 12, what should they remember?
options: Their faithful witness serves as a sign from God, even if rejected
They should only witness to those who listen
They should stop witnessing if people are rebellious
They should change their message to fit popular opinion
questions.correctAnswer: Their faithful witness serves as a sign from God, even if rejected
questions.explanation: Ezekiel was a sign to the rebellious house of Israel, obeying God despite their rejection (Ezekiel 12:6, 12:11). Faithful witness is valuable regardless of response (Ezekiel 12:2, 12:9).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 12 instruct us to handle fear and anxiety in daily living?
options: To live with trembling and carefulness, acknowledging God's sovereignty
To ignore fear and act recklessly
To rely solely on human strength
To avoid thinking about difficulties
questions.correctAnswer: To live with trembling and carefulness, acknowledging God's sovereignty
questions.explanation: God commands Ezekiel to eat bread and drink water with trembling and carefulness, indicating reverent fear and seriousness in difficult times (Ezekiel 12:18-19).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 12 teach about God’s justice and discipline in the community?
options: God will scatter and punish the rebellious but also preserve a remnant
God will ignore rebellion
God will punish only individuals without community consequences
God will always protect the rebellious
questions.correctAnswer: God will scatter and punish the rebellious but also preserve a remnant
questions.explanation: God declares He will scatter those around the prince and punish them, but will also leave a few to survive and declare His name (Ezekiel 12:14-16).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel was commanded to _______________ through the wall in the sight of the people as a sign.
options: dig
build
paint
destroy
questions.correctAnswer: dig
questions.explanation: God commanded Ezekiel to dig through the wall in the sight of the people as a sign of the captivity to come (Ezekiel 12:5-7).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 12 guide believers in handling trials that involve loss or exile?
options: By submitting humbly and trusting God’s plan even when it involves hardship
By resisting all trials to avoid loss
By blaming others for difficulties
By ignoring God’s warnings
questions.correctAnswer: By submitting humbly and trusting God’s plan even when it involves hardship
questions.explanation: Ezekiel’s act of covering his face and carrying belongings into captivity symbolizes humble submission and trust in God’s plan despite hardship (Ezekiel 12:6, 12:12-13).

questions.question: What promise does Ezekiel 12 give to those who faithfully endure God's discipline?
options: They will be part of a remnant who will know the LORD and declare His name
They will avoid all hardship
They will be immediately restored without repentance
They will be forgotten by God
questions.correctAnswer: They will be part of a remnant who will know the LORD and declare His name
questions.explanation: God promises to leave a few who will survive and declare His name among the nations, showing hope for those who endure (Ezekiel 12:16).

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 12 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 12.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 12, what symbolic action does the prophet perform to serve as a sign to the house of Israel?
options: He prepares and removes his belongings by day before digging through a wall at twilight
He builds an altar and offers a sacrifice in the city
He fasts for forty days and nights on a mountaintop
He writes a scroll and burns it publicly
questions.correctAnswer: He prepares and removes his belongings by day before digging through a wall at twilight
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:3-6 describes Ezekiel preparing his stuff for removing by day, digging through the wall in their sight at twilight, and carrying it on his shoulder as a sign to Israel.

questions.question: What is the significance of Ezekiel covering his face as he carries his belongings in Ezekiel 12?
options: To symbolize the prince of Jerusalem who will not see the land of exile
To hide his identity from the people
To mourn for the destruction of the temple
To signify his role as a priest
questions.correctAnswer: To symbolize the prince of Jerusalem who will not see the land of exile
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:6 and 12:12 indicate that covering the face represents the prince who will be taken captive and will not see the land he is taken to.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 12, what will happen to the prince and his bands who assist him?
options: They will be scattered toward every wind and pursued by the sword
They will escape to Egypt for refuge
They will be forgiven and restored to their land
They will build a new city in Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: They will be scattered toward every wind and pursued by the sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:14 explains that those about the prince who help him will be scattered and the sword will be drawn after them.

questions.question: What is the purpose of leaving a 'few men' alive according to Ezekiel 12?
options: To declare the abominations among the nations and know that God is the LORD
To rebuild the temple in Jerusalem
To lead a rebellion against Babylon
To write new prophecies for future generations
questions.correctAnswer: To declare the abominations among the nations and know that God is the LORD
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:16 states that a remnant will be preserved from sword, famine, and pestilence to declare their abominations among the nations and recognize the LORD.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 12, how are the people of Israel described concerning their perception and hearing?
options: They have eyes to see but see not, and ears to hear but hear not
They are blind and deaf by divine punishment
They are enlightened and attentive to the prophet's words
They have closed hearts and refuse to listen
questions.correctAnswer: They have eyes to see but see not, and ears to hear but hear not
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:2 describes Israel as a rebellious house with eyes to see but not seeing and ears to hear but not hearing.

questions.question: What proverb in Israel does God say He will make cease in Ezekiel 12?
options: "The days are prolonged, and every vision faileth"
"The mountains shall move but the law shall stand"
"A prophet is not without honor except in his own country"
"The lion shall lie down with the lamb"
questions.correctAnswer: "The days are prolonged, and every vision faileth"
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:22-23 addresses the proverb 'The days are prolonged, and every vision faileth' and God declares He will make it cease.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 12 foreshadow the Babylonian exile of Judah and Jerusalem's prince?
options: By depicting Ezekiel's removal of belongings and covering his face as a sign of captivity
By calling for a festival to celebrate the king's reign
By describing a victorious battle against foreign nations
By prophesying the immediate restoration of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: By depicting Ezekiel's removal of belongings and covering his face as a sign of captivity
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:3-13 symbolically depicts the prince's exile to Babylon, including digging through the wall and covering the face, foreshadowing the captivity.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 12, what will be the response of the cities that are inhabited after the LORD’s judgment?
options: They shall be laid waste and the land shall be desolate
They will flourish and multiply
They will rebel and fight successfully
They will become centers of worship for foreign gods
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be laid waste and the land shall be desolate
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:20 declares that inhabited cities will be laid waste and the land desolate as a sign of God's judgment.

questions.question: What does the LORD say about His word and visions in Ezekiel 12:24-25?
options: There will be no more vain visions or flattering divinations; His word will come to pass without delay
Visions will be prolonged and His word delayed
Visions will only come through foreign prophets
His word will be symbolic and open to interpretation
questions.correctAnswer: There will be no more vain visions or flattering divinations; His word will come to pass without delay
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:24-25 explains that false visions will cease and God's word will be fulfilled promptly in the days of the rebellious house.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 12, what is the reason given for the desolation of the land and the careful eating and drinking of the people?
options: Because of the violence of all who dwell therein
Because of a drought sent by God
Because of the people's idolatry
Because of the prophet's curse
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the violence of all who dwell therein
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:19 states that the land becomes desolate due to the violence of its inhabitants, causing them to eat and drink with carefulness and astonishment.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 12 connect to the theme of prophetic sign-acts found elsewhere in the Bible?
options: Ezekiel’s removal of belongings mimics prophetic acts like Jeremiah’s yoke and Hosea’s marriage
It is a unique act with no biblical parallels
It parallels Elijah’s confrontation with the prophets of Baal
It repeats Moses’ lifting of the serpent in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: Ezekiel’s removal of belongings mimics prophetic acts like Jeremiah’s yoke and Hosea’s marriage
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12 uses symbolic actions as prophetic signs similar to Jeremiah’s yoke (Jeremiah 27) and Hosea’s marriage (Hosea 1), conveying impending exile and judgment.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 12 reveal about the nature of Israel’s rebellion in terms of perception and obedience?
options: They see and hear but do not understand or obey, making them a rebellious house
They are completely blind and deaf to all messages
They obey but lack faith
They fully accept the prophet’s words
questions.correctAnswer: They see and hear but do not understand or obey, making them a rebellious house
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:2 highlights that Israel has eyes and ears but fails to see and hear, illustrating their stubborn rebellion.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 12, the prince who will be taken captive will see the land of Babylon before his death.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:13 states that the prince will be taken to Babylon but will not see it, though he will die there.

questions.question: What literary device is most prominent in Ezekiel 12’s depiction of the prophet’s actions and the future exile?
options: Typology, where Ezekiel’s actions prefigure the prince’s captivity
Parable, teaching a moral lesson through story
Allegory, representing abstract ideas through characters
Chiasm, arranging ideas in a mirror structure
questions.correctAnswer: Typology, where Ezekiel’s actions prefigure the prince’s captivity
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12 uses typology by having the prophet enact the exile to symbolize and foreshadow the prince’s actual captivity.

questions.question: How does the theme of prophetic authority in Ezekiel 12 compare to other prophetic books like Isaiah or Jeremiah?
options: Ezekiel emphasizes immediate fulfillment and the certainty of God’s word, similar to Jeremiah’s warnings
Ezekiel focuses solely on visions with no emphasis on action
Ezekiel downplays God’s sovereignty unlike Isaiah
Ezekiel rejects the use of symbolic actions unlike other prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Ezekiel emphasizes immediate fulfillment and the certainty of God’s word, similar to Jeremiah’s warnings
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:25-28 stresses God’s word will no longer be delayed but fulfilled, paralleling Jeremiah’s strong emphasis on prophetic certainty.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 12 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 12 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason Ezekiel is told to prepare for removal and carry out his belongings in the sight of the rebellious house?
options: To serve as a sign to the house of Israel
To hide his actions from the people
To demonstrate his strength
To fulfill a personal prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: To serve as a sign to the house of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:6 states that God set Ezekiel as a sign to the house of Israel by carrying out his belongings visibly. This act symbolizes the impending exile and serves as a prophetic demonstration, consistent with God’s use of signs in Numbers 21:8-9, Isaiah 20:3, Matthew 12:39, and Luke 11:29.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 12, what attitude does God ascribe to the house of Israel?
options: Rebellious and unhearing
Faithful and obedient
Joyful and thankful
Wise and understanding
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellious and unhearing
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:2 describes the house of Israel as rebellious with eyes that see but do not perceive and ears that hear but do not understand. This echoes similar descriptions of Israel’s hardness of heart in Isaiah 6:9-10, Jeremiah 5:21, Hebrews 3:8, and Romans 11:7.

questions.question: What symbolic action does Ezekiel perform to represent the captivity of the prince and people of Jerusalem?
options: Digging through a wall and carrying belongings on his shoulder
Building an altar and offering sacrifices
Wearing sackcloth and ashes
Writing a scroll of judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Digging through a wall and carrying belongings on his shoulder
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:5-6 and 12:12 describe Ezekiel digging through a wall and carrying his possessions on his shoulder, covering his face, symbolizing the prince’s captivity and exile. This prophetic action aligns with symbolic acts in Jeremiah 38:6, 1 Kings 18:28, Isaiah 20:2-3, and Acts 21:33-34 where physical acts communicate divine judgment.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 12, what will happen to the prince of Jerusalem as part of God's judgment?
options: He will be taken to Babylon but will not see it before he dies
He will be killed in Jerusalem
He will reign peacefully in exile
He will lead a rebellion against Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: He will be taken to Babylon but will not see it before he dies
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:13 states the prince will be brought to Babylon but will not see it, implying death in exile. This is a fulfillment of judgment consistent with Daniel 9:26, Jeremiah 29:10, 2 Kings 25:7, and Hebrews 11:13 where exile and death are consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: What does God promise will happen to those who assist the prince during the coming judgment?
options: They will be scattered and pursued by the sword
They will be spared and blessed
They will be hidden in the land
They will lead a remnant to safety
questions.correctAnswer: They will be scattered and pursued by the sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:14 describes God scattering those about the prince and drawing out the sword after them. This judgment reflects divine justice seen in 2 Chronicles 36:17, Jeremiah 25:15, Matthew 13:41, and Revelation 19:15 where God executes judgment through dispersion and destruction.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of God leaving a few men from the sword, famine, and pestilence according to Ezekiel 12?
options: They will declare God’s judgments and know Him
They will establish a new kingdom by might
They will forget the abominations of the past
They will deny God and rebel again
questions.correctAnswer: They will declare God’s judgments and know Him
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:16 states God will leave a remnant so they may declare their abominations and acknowledge God. This aligns with the biblical theme of a preserved remnant in Isaiah 10:20-22, Romans 11:5, Zechariah 8:13, and 1 Peter 2:9 highlighting God's faithfulness to preserve a witnessing people.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 12 portray the emotional state God commands Ezekiel to adopt when eating bread and drinking water?
options: With trembling and carefulness
With joy and thanksgiving
With indifference and ease
With anger and rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: With trembling and carefulness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:18 commands Ezekiel to eat and drink with trembling and carefulness, symbolizing the fear and anxiety of the people due to coming desolation. This reflects reverence and awareness of judgment as taught in Proverbs 1:7, Philippians 2:12, Hebrews 12:28-29, and Psalm 34:7.

questions.question: What is the reason given in Ezekiel 12 for the desolation of the land and cities?
options: Because of the violence of those who dwell there
Because of a natural disaster
Because of foreign invasion alone
Because of famine only
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the violence of those who dwell there
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:19 explains the land’s desolation results from the violence committed by its inhabitants. This cause-effect between sin and judgment is consistent with Genesis 6:11, Jeremiah 22:3, Micah 6:8, and Romans 1:18-32 which link human wickedness with divine judgment.

questions.question: What proverb in the land of Israel does Ezekiel 12 challenge, and what does God declare about it?
options: ‘The days are prolonged, and every vision faileth’; God will cause it to cease
‘The Lord is slow to anger’; God will hasten judgment
‘The land shall never be desolate’; God will allow desolation
‘The prince shall reign forever’; God will remove him
questions.correctAnswer: ‘The days are prolonged, and every vision faileth’; God will cause it to cease
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:22-23 addresses the proverb about delayed visions and declares that God will cause it to cease, affirming the certainty and imminence of His word. This relates to biblical teachings on fulfilled prophecy in Isaiah 46:10, Habakkuk 2:3, 2 Peter 1:19, and Revelation 22:6.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 12, what characteristic of God's word is emphasized concerning the timing of prophecy?
options: God’s word will no longer be prolonged but will come to pass promptly
God’s word is always delayed for many years
God’s word is uncertain and symbolic
God’s word depends on human interpretation
questions.correctAnswer: God’s word will no longer be prolonged but will come to pass promptly
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:25 and 12:28 emphasize that God’s word will be fulfilled without delay, highlighting His sovereign control over history. This is consistent with 2 Samuel 7:28, Isaiah 55:11, John 10:35, and Hebrews 6:17-18 where God’s promises are sure and timely.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 12 reveal about the nature of visions and divinations within the house of Israel in the time of judgment?
options: There will be no more vain visions nor flattering divinations
Visions will increase and become more flattering
Divinations will replace the true word of God
False prophets will be exalted
questions.correctAnswer: There will be no more vain visions nor flattering divinations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:24 states that vain visions and flattering divinations will cease, showing God’s commitment to truth over false prophecy. This resonates with Deuteronomy 18:22, Jeremiah 14:14, 1 Corinthians 14:29, and 2 Timothy 3:13 condemning false prophecy.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 12 describe the people's misunderstanding of the prophet's vision and message?
options: They say the vision is for many days to come and prophesies of far-off times
They accept the vision immediately as present truth
They reject the vision because it is too recent
They believe the vision is symbolic only
questions.correctAnswer: They say the vision is for many days to come and prophesies of far-off times
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:27 describes the people’s claim that the vision refers to distant times. God refutes this in verse 28 by affirming the immediacy of His word’s fulfillment. Similar misunderstandings occurred in Habakkuk 1:2, Isaiah 5:19, 2 Peter 3:4, and Luke 21:32.

questions.question: What action does God instruct Ezekiel to take as a prophetic sign showing the certainty of exile?
options: Remove his belongings publicly during daylight and carry them at twilight
Build a replica of Babylon in Jerusalem
Offer sacrifices on behalf of the people
Write down prophecies on scrolls
questions.correctAnswer: Remove his belongings publicly during daylight and carry them at twilight
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:3-6 commands Ezekiel to remove belongings in the sight of the people, symbolizing exile. This dramatic prophetic action parallels Jonah 1:3, Isaiah 20:2-3, Jeremiah 13:1-7, and Matthew 24:15 where physical signs communicate divine warnings.

questions.question: What does God declare will be the result when He scatters the people among the nations according to Ezekiel 12?
options: They shall know that He is the LORD
They shall forget their God
They shall establish new gods
They shall prosper without Him
questions.correctAnswer: They shall know that He is the LORD
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:15 and 12:16 affirm that scattering will lead to the recognition of God’s sovereignty. This theme of recognition after judgment is also seen in Deuteronomy 28:64, Jeremiah 24:7, Ezekiel 39:27, and Romans 11:26, highlighting God’s ultimate redemptive purpose.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 12 characterize the prophet’s role in relation to the prince and the people experiencing exile?
options: Ezekiel is a sign and example of what will happen to them
Ezekiel is a secret messenger for the prince alone
Ezekiel is to hide the truth to protect them

questions.correctAnswer: Ezekiel is a sign and example of what will happen to them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 12:10-11 shows Ezekiel acting as a sign, doing as the prince and people will do—going into captivity. This prophetic typology aligns with Jeremiah 27:2-3, Hosea 8:1, John 10:24-25, and Acts 3:18 where prophets embody their message.
